content: in order i used this as my reference throughout the project and would recommend that you make one too obviously you may well have leftover yarn to use but should you want to use the same colours as me i ve listed them on the next page 2 red bright pink blue aster lipstick lapis claret royal orange tomato indigo emperor spice proper purple clementine plum yellow saffron violet boysenberry sunshine fuchsia purple dandelion pomegranate green mustard lime apple as well as your 21 little balls of yarn you ll need lots of black yarn and a 3 5 mm crochet hook this should give you a nice firm gauge which is important for this sort of crochet i bought 600g of black yarn and ended up using about 520g of it the finished blanket measures roughly 116 x 100 cm or 46 x 39 this pattern uses british crochet terms double_crochet = us single_crochet half_double_crochet = us half_double_crochet treble_crochet = us double_crochet 3 the first square all 42 squares are worked in the same way it s just the order of the colours that changes for this first square you will be using the first three colours on your shade card - that is the three shades of red in the instructions that follow i ll distinguish the three shades within each set of colours by numbering them c1 c2 and c3 following the order they appear on the shade card just to confuse you the photos show my blue squares being crocheted they photographed better than the red ones but the crochet is the same for all seven sets of colours a few notes every round ends with a slip_stitch into the first stitch of the round a slip_stitch is then worked to change to the new colour the black yarn is carried without cutting throughout the square all corners worked into the corner spaces from the previous round consist of double_crochet 2ch double_crochet apart from the corners all double_crochet stitches are worked into the back half of the stitch only all treble stitches are worked into the front half of the stitch two rounds below i will explain in more detail as we go along but these notes might be useful to refer back to one more thing - don t try to count the rounds on the right side you can only really count them on the back round 1 using black make four chain stitches and join with a slip_stitch into a ring still using black work the first round 3 chain counts as double_crochet 2ch double_crochet 2ch x 3 slip_stitch to first chain space this gives you a tiny not very exciting square 4 round 2 change to c1 with a slip_stitch and work double_crochet 2ch double_crochet into the corner space the rest of the round is very simple double_crochet double_crochet 2ch double_crochet in corner double_crochet x 3 slip_stitch to first double_crochet of round round 3 change back to black with a slip_stitch and
